{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3492211,"name":"Battery Nerd - FRC #4561","username":"sdtrent","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/s/9de053/{size}.png","created_at":"2025-01-25T04:42:46.088Z","cooked":"

Last season’s high-energy impacts led the team to use zip ties to prevent power loss or reboots caused by SB50 connector contact bounce. This solution worked well, for the most part. However, we did lose power in one match, even with a zip-tied SB50 connector. The issue occurred because the student installing the battery didn’t realize how tight the zip tie needed to be or how to orient it for a solid connection.

We wanted a solution that was more foolproof. We began by reviewing other SB50 clamp designs on Chief Delphi and creating a wish list of features.

Desired Clamp Features

  • Reusable
  • Single-piece design (no second clip part to misplace)
  • Stays attached to the robot (so it can’t be forgotten)
  • No tools required (no snips needed for removal)
  • Quick to apply and remove
  • High visibility when installed

We believe we achieved all of our design goals with a minimal retention device that is intuitive to use once applied to the robot. We implemented the clip starting with our second Crescendo competition, and we had no further power glitches throughout our rounds in Houston. Take a look and see if you think this design could help your team reduce power issues:

https://makerworld.com/en/models/1034629#profileId-1018121

Design Details

We decided to use the existing holes in the SB50 connector, as many other clamp designs do. A 6-32 bolt proved to be the best fit using off-the-shelf hardware.

Hardware Required

  • A long 6-32 bolt (1.5" or 1.625") to attach the clip to the robot’s SB50 connector, retained with a nylock nut (engaging two or three threads).
  • A shorter 6-32 bolt (0.75") to secure the clip to the battery SB50 connector.
  • A hook-and-loop strap to hold the clip in place after attaching the short bolt to the battery SB50 connector.

Assembly and Orientation

The orientation of the clip depends on your robot’s SB50 connector configuration:

  • Flat side up: Attach the clip to the most visible side of the robot’s SB50 connector after the battery is connected.
  • Valley side up: Ensure the long bolt is inserted into the side that allows the clip to mate flat against the top of the robot’s SB50 connector.

This design ensures the clip stays securely attached and visible. The photos below illustrate both configurations:

  • Flat side up

    .

  • Valley side up

Early Design Prototype on Test Robot

Here is an early prototype of the clip on our test robot, demonstrating how it stays attached to the robot’s SB50 connector:

2024-08-24 14.25.161920×1440 178 KB

Clip Alignment with Attached Battery SB50

SB50 Alignment1920×1440 226 KB

Engaged and Secured Views

  • Top View

    SB50 engaged and secured1920×1252 197 KB

  • Profile View

    2024-08-24 14.26.411920×1440 173 KB

  • Bottom View

    SB50 engaged and secured bottom1920×1383 202 KB

I hope you find this useful. Good luck out there!

Shane
Battery Nerd
Mentor - FRC 4561 - TerrorBytes
